deliberation: I checked whether the thirst, water, buying, wine, and milk could be literal, but in the context of the chapter they clearly stand for spiritual need and divine provision, expressed through commercial and food imagery. All of these images work together as one extended metaphor of free spiritual nourishment, rather than several separate figures.

instances.hebrew_text: הוֹי כׇּל־צָמֵא לְכוּ לַמַּיִם ... לְכוּ שִׁבְרוּ וֶאֱכֹלוּ ... בְּלוֹא־כֶסֶף וּבְלֹא מְחִיר יַיִן וְחָלָב
instances.english_text: Ho, all who are thirsty, come for water … Come, buy food and eat: Buy food without money, wine and milk without cost.

Physical thirst, food and drink, and commercial transaction

Gratuitous, satisfying provision that meets essential need
Experiential / affective domain (hunger, satisfaction, relief)

Exhortation and promise aimed at persuading hearers to respond
Rhetorical / pragmatic function
instances.explanation: Physical thirst and the act of buying food and drink without money metaphorically depict the people's spiritual hunger and God's free, abundant provision of salvation and teaching.

deliberation: I looked at whether the money, bread, and labor language could be taken literally. In context it contrasts false pursuits with heeding God, and the "eating good" and "delighting in fatness" clearly picture spiritual satisfaction through listening to God. This forms a single, coherent eating/feasting metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: לָמָּה תִשְׁקְלוּ־כֶסֶף בְּלוֹא־לֶחֶם וִיגִיעֲכֶם בְּלֹא לְשׇׂבְעָה שִׁמְעוּ שָׁמוֹעַ אֵלַי וְאִכְלוּ־טוֹב וְתִתְעַנַּג בַּדֶּשֶׁן נַפְשְׁכֶם
instances.english_text: Why do you spend money for what is not bread, your earnings for what does not satisfy? Give heed to Me, and you shall eat choice food and enjoy the richest viands.
target: The people's pursuit of false sources of fulfillment versus true satisfaction in heeding God
Human priorities and spiritual satisfaction
Moral / spiritual life domain
vehicle: Spending money on non-bread that does not satisfy, versus eating good food and delighting in rich fatness
Economic expenditure and bodily nourishment (lean versus rich food)
Material / bodily experience domain
ground: Exerting effort and resources on what fails versus what truly satisfies and delights
Contrast between futility and genuine fulfillment
Evaluative / experiential domain
posture: Reproof of misguided pursuits combined with an attractive promise of true enjoyment
Admonition plus promise intended to redirect desire
Rhetorical / pragmatic function
instances.explanation: The verse metaphorically portrays misguided spiritual and moral pursuits as buying non-bread that cannot satisfy, while attentive listening to God is depicted as eating excellent, rich food that delights the inner self.

deliberation: I examined the bodily and auditory terms ('incline your ear,' 'come to Me,' 'hear and your soul shall live') to see whether they are literal. Since the call is to respond to God's word, not to physically move, the language of inclining the ear and coming functions metaphorically for attentive, obedient response.

instances.hebrew_text: הַטּוּ אׇזְנְכֶם וּלְכוּ אֵלַי שִׁמְעוּ וּתְחִי נַפְשְׁכֶם

Spiritual attentiveness and conversion
Theological / moral response domain
vehicle: Physically inclining the ear, coming to someone, and living soul
Bodily posture and spatial approach toward a speaker
Embodied / spatial experience domain
ground: Drawing near and paying close attention as the way to receive life-giving words
Attentive presence leads to life and relationship
Relational / communicative domain
posture: An earnest appeal inviting intimate, obedient listening
Exhortation to relational closeness with God through His word
Rhetorical / pastoral function
instances.explanation: Leaning the ear and coming to God are not literal movements but metaphors for careful listening and turning one’s inner self toward God in order to receive life through His covenant promises.

deliberation: I checked whether the titles 'witness to the peoples, leader, and commander' are purely literal offices or figurative. 'Witness' (עֵד) is taken from legal testimony and applied to a royal/messianic figure in relation to the nations, extending the courtroom term into a broader exemplary role. This constitutes a conceptual metaphor, while 'leader and commander' can be taken straightforwardly as roles.

instances.english_text: As I made him a witness to peoples
target: The royal/messianic figure’s role of making God’s purposes known among the nations
Testimony about God through a person’s life and rule
Theological / missional domain
vehicle: A legal witness who gives testimony before others
Courtroom role of a testifying witness
Judicial / forensic domain
ground: Publicly declaring and embodying truth before an audience
Representative disclosure of God’s will and character
Communicative / representative domain
posture: Affirmation of the exalted role assigned to the Davidic figure
Divine declaration of vocation before the nations
Rhetorical / proclamatory function
instances.explanation: Calling the Davidic figure a 'witness to the peoples' borrows courtroom language: his person and reign testify before the nations to who God is and what He does, functioning metaphorically as legal testimony on a world stage.

deliberation: I considered whether the nations 'running' to Israel and not knowing/knowing Israel are figurative. Within prophetic expectation, this can be read quite literally as nations physically and politically coming to Zion because of God's glory. While 'nation' can function as a collective for its people, that is standard usage rather than a distinctive literary figure here. I therefore did not isolate a clear figurative device of the types requested.

I evaluated 'seek YHWH' and 'call Him while He is near.' Since God is not a physical object in space, the verbs of seeking and spatial nearness are metaphorical mappings from physical searching and proximity onto relational/spiritual accessibility.

instances.hebrew_text: דִּרְשׁוּ יְהוָה בְּהִמָּצְאוֹ קְרָאֻהוּ בִּהְיוֹתוֹ קָרוֹב

Spiritual access to and relationship with God
Theological / relational domain
vehicle: Searching for someone who can be found; calling to someone who is near in space
Physical seeking and spatial nearness
Embodied / spatial experience domain
ground: Urgently approaching someone who is currently accessible before the opportunity passes
Openness and availability inviting pursuit and contact
Temporal / relational opportunity domain
posture: An urgent exhortation to respond within a limited window of divine accessibility
Warning mixed with invitation
Rhetorical / hortatory function
instances.explanation: The verse uses physical searching and spatial nearness to picture the relational and spiritual accessibility of God: repentance and prayer are framed as seeking and calling to a God who is presently 'near.'

deliberation: I noted two distinct but related metaphors: (1) 'way' for a person's pattern of life or conduct, which the wicked must abandon, and (2) 'return to YHWH' as an image of repentance pictured as coming back to a person or place. These are closely connected but employ different vehicles (path vs. homecoming), so I treat them as two separate figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: Let the wicked give up their way
target: The wicked person's habitual behavior and lifestyle
Moral conduct and life-pattern
Ethical / behavioral domain
vehicle: A 'way' or road that one travels on and can leave
Physical path or road
Spatial / travel domain
ground: A path one chooses and follows can be left for another route
Directionality and continuity that shape one’s course
Life-course / decision-making domain
posture: Moral exhortation to abandon an entrenched pattern of evil conduct
Call to radical change of course
Rhetorical / hortatory function
instances.explanation: The verse pictures a person’s pattern of life as a 'way' or road and calls the wicked to forsake that road, metaphorically urging them to abandon their established course of evil behavior.

instances.english_text: Let each one turn back to GOD so as to be pardoned
target: The inner act of repentance and renewed devotion to God
Spiritual and relational change toward God
Theological / relational domain
vehicle: Returning to someone one has left or strayed from
Physical turning back or coming home
Spatial / relational movement domain
ground: Moving back toward a person restores proximity and relationship
Reversal of direction signals renewed association
Reconciliation / restoration domain
posture: Invitation with promise of mercy to those who turn back
Assurance designed to encourage repentance
Rhetorical / pastoral function
instances.explanation: Repentance is cast as a physical 'return' to YHWH, borrowing imagery of coming back to someone one has left, in order to portray restored relationship and the reception of divine compassion and pardon.

deliberation: I considered 'thoughts' and 'ways.' 'Thoughts' can be taken straightforwardly as plans or intentions, but 'ways' (דְּרָכִים) continues the established metaphor of paths for modes of action. Applied to God, it is clearly not about literal roads but His patterns of acting, so I treat this as a metaphorical use of 'ways.'

instances.english_text: Nor are My ways your ways
target: God’s modes of action, decision, and governance versus human ones
Divine conduct and human conduct
Theological / moral domain
vehicle: Different 'ways' or roads that belong to different travelers
Physical paths as belonging to different people
Spatial / journey domain
ground: Distinct paths imply different directions, destinations, and methods
Incomparability and divergence of course
Evaluation / contrast domain
posture: A corrective assertion emphasizing God’s otherness and superiority
Doctrinal statement to humble human presumption
Rhetorical / didactic function
instances.explanation: The verse uses 'ways' metaphorically for patterns of action, asserting that God’s course of action is fundamentally different from, and not aligned with, human patterns or expectations.

deliberation: I noted the explicit comparison introduced by 'as... so' (כִּי־גָבְהוּ... כֵּן גָּבְהוּ). The great vertical distance between heaven and earth is used as a simile for the qualitative and quantitative superiority of God’s ways and thoughts over human ones. The 'height' itself is metaphorical for superiority.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־גָבְהוּ שָׁמַיִם מֵאָרֶץ כֵּן גָּבְהוּ דְרָכַי מִדַּרְכֵיכֶם וּמַחְשְׁבֹתַי מִמַּחְשְׁבֹתֵיכֶם

target: The immense difference between God’s ways and thoughts and those of humans
Divine transcendence and superiority
Theological / cognitive domain
vehicle: The great vertical distance between the heavens and the earth; 'height' of ways and thoughts
Spatial height and separation in the cosmos
Physical / cosmological domain
ground: A vast, immeasurable gap signifying incomparability and surpassing greatness
Superiority and otherness captured by extreme distance
Evaluative / comparative domain
posture: A humbling, awe-inspiring assertion of God’s transcendence
Didactic and worship-evoking statement
Rhetorical / theological function
instances.explanation: The verse explicitly compares the great height of heaven over earth to the superiority of God’s ways and thoughts over human ones, using spatial height as a simile—and in its extremity, a hyperbolic image—for divine transcendence.

deliberation: Most of the verse straightforwardly describes the natural cycle of rain and snow, but the phrase 'makes it give birth and sprout' uses childbirth language for the earth producing vegetation. That is a personification/metaphor, since the earth does not literally bear children.

instances.english_text: But soaks the earth and makes it bring forth vegetation, and makes it sprout

Fruitfulness and productivity of the land
Agricultural / ecological domain
vehicle: Causing the earth to 'give birth' and sprout
Childbearing and growth ascribed to the land
Human / biological reproduction domain
ground: From within the earth, new life emerges as offspring come from a mother
Internal generation and visible emergence of life
Growth / generativity domain
posture: Poetic vividness to highlight the life-giving role of rain
Descriptive praise of the natural order as God’s instrument
Rhetorical / illustrative function
instances.explanation: The earth is personified as a mother that 'gives birth' when rain waters it, metaphorically describing the emergence of vegetation as childbirth.

deliberation: Here the word from God is compared to the rain of v.10 and, more specifically, is described as 'going out' from God’s mouth, 'not returning' empty, 'doing' and 'succeeding' and being 'sent.' This is an extended metaphor and personification of the word as an effective agent or messenger.

instances.hebrew_text: כֵּן יִהְיֶה דְבָרִי אֲשֶׁר יֵצֵא מִפִּי לֹא־יָשׁוּב אֵלַי רֵיקָם כִּי אִם־עָשָׂה אֶת־אֲשֶׁר חָפַצְתִּי וְהִצְלִיחַ אֲשֶׁר שְׁלַחְתִּיו

Divine speech as effective action
Theological / performative domain
vehicle: A word that goes out from someone’s mouth, is sent on a mission, does work, and returns not empty
A personal agent or messenger dispatched to accomplish a task

Agency / causation domain

Strengthening trust in the effectiveness of divine speech
Rhetorical / reassuring function
instances.explanation: God’s 'word' is personified as a sent agent or messenger that goes out, fulfills its mission, and returns with results, metaphorically expressing the unfailing efficacy of divine speech.

deliberation: I distinguished the exiles' going out in joy (which can be literal departure from captivity, though filled with joy) from two clear personifications of nature: mountains and hills bursting into song, and trees clapping their hands. These are two distinct images, using different human actions (singing vs. clapping) applied to different parts of creation.

instances.explanation: Mountains and hills are personified as if they can burst out in joyful song, hyperbolically portraying the entire landscape as celebrating Israel’s joyful liberation.

instances.explanation: Trees are depicted as clapping their hands, a human act of joyous applause, personifying creation to emphasize the overflowing, world-embracing joy at Israel’s restoration.

deliberation: I examined whether the vegetation change is merely ecological prediction or symbolic. Given the covenantal context and contrast (thornbush/nettle vs. cypress/myrtle), the plants function as images of curse/desolation versus blessing/beauty; their replacement represents transformation of the people’s condition. This constitutes a single, coherent metaphor, with 'name' and 'sign' expressing the enduring reputation and testimony but not needing separate instances here.

instances.hebrew_text: תַּחַת הַנַּעֲצוּץ יַעֲלֶה בְרֹשׁ וְתַחַת הַסִּרְפַּד יַעֲלֶה הֲדַס

Agricultural / botanical domain

Movement from ugliness and harm to beauty and usefulness
Evaluation / transformation domain
posture: Assurance of a profound, observable transformation that will testify to YHWH
Promise of a visible, lasting sign of God’s saving work
Rhetorical / promissory function
instances.explanation: The swap of thorny, worthless vegetation for valuable, beautiful trees metaphorically depicts the transformation from a cursed, desolate state to a blessed, flourishing one, serving as a living sign and reputation for YHWH.
